## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
2. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
3. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
4. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
5. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
6. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
7. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
8. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
9. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
10. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
11. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
12. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
13. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Genetic research will improve our lives.
16. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
17. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
18. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
19. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
20. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
21. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
22. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
23. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
24. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
25. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
26. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
27. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
28. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
29. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
30. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
33. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
34. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
35. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
36. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
37. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
38. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
39. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
40. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
41. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
42. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
45. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
46. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
47. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
48. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
49. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize privacy and public control with strong oversight for biobanking.

3. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
4. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
5. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
6. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
7. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
8. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
9. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
10. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
11. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
12. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
13. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
14. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
15. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
16. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
17. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
18. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
19. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
20. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
21. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
22. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
23. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
24. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
25. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
26. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
27. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
28. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
29. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
30. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
31. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
32. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
33. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
34. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
35. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
36. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
37. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
38. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
39. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
40. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
41. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
42. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 42 [Considerations] below from 1 to 12, where 1 is strongly disagree and 12 is strongly agree.

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
2. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
3. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
4. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
5. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
6. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
7. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
8. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
9. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
10. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
11. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
12. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
13. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
14. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
15. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
16. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
17. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
18. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
19. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
20. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
21. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
22. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
23. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
24. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
25. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.
26. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
27. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
28. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
29. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
30. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
31. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
32. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
33. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
34. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
35. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
36. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
37. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
38. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
39. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
40. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
41. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
42. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 5 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 5, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 5 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 5 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.

- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Stabilize trouble spots is best, closing is ideal but unrealistic, maintain current is ok, upgrade to dirt is meh, bitumen is worst.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 48 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 48 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 48 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
2. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
3. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
4. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
5. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
6. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
7. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
8. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
9. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
10. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
11. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
12. We are a democratic country.
13. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
14. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
15. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
16. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
17. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
18. People get the government they deserve
19. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
20. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
21. I'm always cynical about government processes.
22. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
23. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
24. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
25. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition. 
26. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
27. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
28. We live in a great democracy.
29. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
30. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
31. Too few people have a lot of sway in the system.  Corporate lobbyists, vested interests, pork barrelling and contributions to political parties are all problematic.
32. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
33. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
34. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
35. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
36. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
37. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
38. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.
39. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
40. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
41. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
42. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
43. There is no real difference in ideological terms between the major parties and preference distributions are problematic.
44. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
45. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
46. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
47. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
48. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 5 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 5, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 5 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 5 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 5 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Government with strong leaders and legislation that ensures that proper moral principles are observed in society.
2. The kind of government that we have, with no major changes
3. Government that abolishes all policies that give special benefits to minority groups, and instead ensures equal influence for all Australians
4. Government with guaranteed involvement by all social groups, especially those representing disadvantaged minorities, in policy making
5. A government with constitutional rules specifying its main task is to ensure that economic markets work well, and that government intervenes as little in society beyond that

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I value inclusivity and social justice over traditional morality and minimal government intervention.

10. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
11. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
12. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
13. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
14. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
15. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition.

19. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.

25. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.

27. People get the government they deserve
28. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
29. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
30. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
31. The political system is remote and closed and the connection with elected representatives is difficult, they are often faceless.
32. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
33. I'm always cynical about government processes.
34. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
35. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
36. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
37. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
38. I don't think there's anything wrong with people voting for their self-interest.
39. We live in a great democracy.
40. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
41. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
42. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
43. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
44. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
45. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
46. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
47. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
48. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
2. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
3. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
4. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
5. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
6. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
7. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
8. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
9. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
10. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
11. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
12. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
13. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
14. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
15. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
16. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
17. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
18. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
19. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
20. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
21. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
22. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
23. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
24. Forest health means jobs.
25. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
26. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
27. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
28. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
29. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
30. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
31. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
32. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
33. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
34. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
35. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
36. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
37. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
38. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
39. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
40. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
41. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
42. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
43. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
44. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
45. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
2. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
3. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
4. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
5. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
6. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
7. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize balance of ecological and social values, minimal intervention, and fire's natural role.

44. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.

21. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
22. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
23. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
24. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
25. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
26. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
27. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
28. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
29. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
30. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
31. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
32. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
33. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
34. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
35. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
36. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
37. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
38. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
39. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
40. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
41. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
42. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
43. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
44. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
45. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.

17. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
18. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
19. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
20. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
21. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
22. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
23. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
24. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
25. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
26. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
27. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
28. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
29. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
30. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
31. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
32. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
33. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
34. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
35. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
36. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
37. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
38. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
39. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
40. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
41. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
42. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
43. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
44. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
45. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 38 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 38 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 38 lines in total.

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
2. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks. 
3. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits. 
4. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
5. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.  
6. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.  
7. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
8. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.  
9. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government. 
10. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.  
11. Genetic research will improve our lives.
12. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime. 
13. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples. 
14. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank. 
15. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
16. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
17. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
18. Genetic information is different from health information. 
19. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
20. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
21. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.  
22. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
23. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
24. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
25. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
26. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research. 
27. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities. 
28. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
29. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
30. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me. 
31. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
32. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research. 
33. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
34. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
35. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone. 
36. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
37. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community. 
38. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
2. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to ensure benefits to society or the community (e.g., geographical, ethno-cultural) participating in a collection of data and biological samples.
3. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals ONLY when the individual is identifiable.
4. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g., research ethics board), regardless of whether the individual is identifiable.
5. Regardless of privacy and oversight, it is most important to prevent discrimination (e.g., through insurance, social attitudes) that might result from research on collections of data and biological samples.
6. Every use of stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individuals, even if the use does not identify the individual.
7. Use of stored data and biological samples for research requires authorization from individuals only when they are identifiable AND approval by an appropriate governing body (e.g. research ethics board) when they are not identifiable.

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.

response: Individual control is paramount, even for anonymized data, with strong oversight for all research.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 30 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 30 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 30 lines in total.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
2. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
3. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
4. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
5. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
6. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
7. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
8. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
9. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
10. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
11. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
12. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
13. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
14. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
15. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
16. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
17. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
18. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
19. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
20. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
21. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
22. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
23. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
24. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
25. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
26. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
27. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
28. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
29. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
30. Food waste is a major environmental issue

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Political measures that include moderate regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning certain pesticides, providing incentives for organic farming).
2. Leave the policy settings as they are.
3. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
4. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).
5. Political measures that include radical regulation toward sustainable food production (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the import of foods produced using unsustainable methods).
6. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I support moderate regulation and incentives for sustainable food production.

3. Political measures that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable foods (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products).
4. Political measures aimed at investing in research to develop sustainable agricultural techniques or materials.
5. Political measures that focus on less regulation  (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulations)
6. Leave the policy settings as they are.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I support moderate regulation and incentives for sustainable local production.

1. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.

3. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
4. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.

13. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
14. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
15. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
16. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
17. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
18. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
19. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
20. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
21. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
22. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
23. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
24. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
25. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
26. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
27. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
28. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
29. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
30. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
31. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
32. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.

- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize proactive adaptation and significant emissions reduction over inaction or solely economic growth.

- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
2. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
3. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
4. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
5. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
6. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
7. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.
8. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
9. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
10. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous. 
11. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
12. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
13. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
14. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
15. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
16. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
17. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
18. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.
19. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
20. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.
21. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
22. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
23. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
24. Since the traffic bridge has important heritage significance, the only grounds for its removal should be on the grounds of serious safety issues and verified by heritage engineers.
25. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
26. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
27. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
28. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
29. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
30. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
31. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.
32. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
33. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
34. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
35. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
36. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
2. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
3. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
4. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
5. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
6. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
7. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
8. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
9. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
10. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
11. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
12. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
13. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
14. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
15. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
16. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
17. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
18. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
19. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
20. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

1. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
2. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
3. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.

response: Prioritize public awareness, integrated services, and addressing socioeconomic factors for mental health.

- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
2. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
3. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
4. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
5. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
6. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
7. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
8. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
9. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
10. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
11. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
12. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
13. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
14. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
15. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
16. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
17. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
18. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
19. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
20. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
2. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.
3. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
4. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
5. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
6. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
7. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: More funding needed for mental health services, especially for disadvantaged groups and integrated approaches.

13. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
14. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
15. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
16. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
17. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
18. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.

20. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
21. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.

23. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.

33. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
34. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
35. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
36. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
37. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
38. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.

42. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
43. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
2. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
3. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
4. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
5.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
6. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
7. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
8. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
9. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
10. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
11. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
12. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
13. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
14. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
15. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
16. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
17. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
18. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
19. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
20. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
21. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
22. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
23. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
24. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
25. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
26. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
27. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
28. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
29. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
30. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
31. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
32. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
33. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
34. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
35. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
36. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
37. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
38. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
39. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
40. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
41. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
42. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
43. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
44. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
45. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Coal
2. Geothermal Energy
3. Wind
4. Solar Energy
5. Nuclear Energy
6. Hydroelectric
7. Coal with CO2 Burial
8. Natural Gas
9. Biomass

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Biomass is most sustainable, followed by geothermal, renewables, then nuclear and gas, with coal and carbon capture least favored.
