prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
2. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
3. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
4. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
5. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
6. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
7. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
8. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
9. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
10. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
11. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
12. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
13. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
14. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
15. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
16. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
17. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
18. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
19. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
20. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
21. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
22. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
23. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
24. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
25. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
26. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
27. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
28. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
29. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
30. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
31. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
32. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
33. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
34. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
35. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
36. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
37.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
38. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
39. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
40. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
41. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
42. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
43. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
44. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
45. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).

- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
2. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
3. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
4. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
5. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
6. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
7. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
8. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
9. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
10. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
11. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
12. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
13. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
14. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
15. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
16. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
17. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
18. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
19. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
20. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
21. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
22. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
23. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
24. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
25. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
26.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
27. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
28. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
29. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
30. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
31. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
32. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
33. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
34. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
35. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
36. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
37. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
38. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
39. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
40. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
41. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
42. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
43. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
44. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
45. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.

2. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
3. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
4. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
5. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
6. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
7. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
8. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
9. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
10. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
11. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
12. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
13. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
14. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
15. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
16. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
17. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
18. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
19. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
20. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
21. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
22. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
23. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
24. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
25. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
26. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
27. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
28. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
29. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
30. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
31. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
32. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
33. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
34. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
35. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
36. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
37.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
38. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
39. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
40. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
41. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
42. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
43. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
44. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
45. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 9 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 9 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Hydroelectric
2. Geothermal Energy
3. Nuclear Energy
4. Coal
5. Natural Gas
6. Wind
7. Coal with CO2 Burial
8. Biomass
9. Solar Energy

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.

8. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
9. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
10. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
11. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
12. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
13. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
14. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
15. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
16. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
17. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
18. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
19. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
20. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
21. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
22.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
23. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
24. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
25. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
26. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
27. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
28. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
29. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
30. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
31. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
32. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
33. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
34. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
35. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
36. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
37. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
38. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
39. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
40. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
41. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
42. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
43. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
44. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
45. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.

11. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
12. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
13. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
14. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
15. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
16. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
17. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
18. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
19. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
20. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
21. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
22. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
23. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
24. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
25. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
26. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
27. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
28. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
29.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
30. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
31. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
32. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
33. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
34. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
35. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
36. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
37. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
38. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
39. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
40. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
41. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
42. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
43. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
44. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
45. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.

1. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
2. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
3. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
4. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
5. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
6. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
7. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
8. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
9. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
10. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
11. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
12. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
13. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
14. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
15. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
16. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
17. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
18. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
19. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
20. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
21. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
22. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
23. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
24. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
25. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
26. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
27. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
28. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
29. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
30. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
31. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
32. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
33. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
34. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
35. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
36. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
2. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
3. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
4. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
5. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
6. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
7. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
8. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
9. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
10. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
11. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
12. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
13. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
14. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
15. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
16. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
17. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
18. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
19. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
20. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
21. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
22. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
23. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
24. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
25. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
26. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
27. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
28. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
29. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
30. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
31. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
32. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
33. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
34. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
35. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
36. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.

3. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
4. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
5. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.

8. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.

11. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.

16. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
17. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine

19. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.

21. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"

24. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union

27. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities

29. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process

31. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services

34. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion

1. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
2. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
3. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
4. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
5. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
6. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
7. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
8. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
9. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
10. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
11. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
12. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
13. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
14. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
15. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
16. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
17. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
18. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
19. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
20. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
21. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
22. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
23. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
24. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
25. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
26. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
27. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
28. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
29. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
30. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
31. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
32. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
33. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
34. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
35. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
2. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
3. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
4. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
5. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
6. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
7. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
8. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
9. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
10. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
11. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
12. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
13. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
14. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
15. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
16. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
17. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
18. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
19. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
20. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
21. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
22. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
23. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
24. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
25. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
26. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
27. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
28. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
29. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
30. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
31. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
32. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
33. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
34. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
35. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
36. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
37. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
38. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
39. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
40. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
41. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
42. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
43. Genome editing is really cool science.
44. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
45. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 8 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 8, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 8 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 8 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 8 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Prohibit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation.
2. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit.
3.  Permit both heritable and non-heritable uses of genome editing for any purpose with minimal restrictions to ensure safety and compliance with ethical standards.
4. Permit only non-heritable human genome editing for clinical treatments, and mitochondrial donation.
5. Permit all uses of human genome editing and mitochondrial donation only if not for profit
6.  Permit only non-heritable human genome editing in both research and in clinics.
7. Permit non-heritable and heritable human genome editing (including mitochondrial donation), but only for clinical purposes, and if there is strong oversight, regular community input and (re)approval.
8. Prohibit all forms of human genome editing for now, except for research purposes.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I favor strict regulation and oversight of genome editing, prioritizing safety and ethical considerations.

9. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.

13. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.

37. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.

42. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
43. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.

45. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.

## [Considerations]:
1. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
2. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
3. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
4. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
5. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
6. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
7. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
8. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
9. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
10. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
11. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
12. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
13. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
14. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
15. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
16. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
17. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
18. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
19. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
20. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
21. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
22. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
23. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
24. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
2. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
3. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
4. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
5. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
6. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
7. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
8. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
9. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
10. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
11. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
12. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
13. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
14. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
15. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
16. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
17. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
18. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
19. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
20. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
21. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
22. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
23. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
24. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
25. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
26. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
27. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
28. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
29. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
30. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
31. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
32. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
33. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
34. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
35. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
36. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
37. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
38. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
39. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
40. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
41. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
42. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
43. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
44. Genetic research will improve our lives.
45. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
46. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
47. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
48. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
49. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
4. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
5. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritize privacy and strong regulation, favoring public or hybrid models with strict oversight.

## [Policies]:
1. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
2. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
3. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
4. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prefer publicly funded biobanks with strong regulation and prioritize individual privacy.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize privacy and cautious implementation with public funding and strong regulation.

1. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
2. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
3. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
4. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
5. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
6. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
7. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
8. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

10. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
11. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
12. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
13. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
14. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
15. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
16. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
17. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
18. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
19. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
20. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
21. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
22. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
23. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
24. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
25. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
26. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
27. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
28. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
29. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
30. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
31. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
32. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
33. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
34. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
35. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
2. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
3. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
4. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
5. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
6. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
7. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
8. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
9. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
10. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
11. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
12. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
13. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
14. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
15. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
16. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
17. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
18. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
19. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
20. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

## [Example output]:

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
2. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
3. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
4. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
5. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.

7. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.

response: Prioritize socioeconomic solutions and increased funding for existing services over privatization or reduction.
